frameDefinitions: The  Speaker expresses through language his wish to get the Addressee to act in some way that will help to bring about events or states described in the Content.
This frame contains verbs and nouns that communicate the act of a Speaker to address a Message to some Addressee using language.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
A condition that is set out in an Agreement imposes Requirements on a Party or parties, with respect to some Regulated_entity.
In this frame a Speaker asks an Addressee for something, or to carry out some action.
frameExamples: Mr Smithers always <t>encourages</t> the employees to stay late and work harder.
I now <t>declare</t> you members of this Society.
Breach of contract occurs where one of the parties fails to perform any one of the contract <t>terms</t> .
listRoleDefinitions: The wish for action on the Addressee's part that the Speaker expresses.
The person that the <fen>Speaker</fen> seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
What the communication is about.
The written or spoken material that contains a message that potentially influences the <fen>Addressee</fen> towards the <fen>Content</fen>.
An entity which the <fen>Speaker</fen> believes should participate in the action.
The time at which the lobbying occurs.
The location where the <fen>Speaker</fen> attemtps susaion on an <fen>Addressee</fen>.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen> (whether spoken or written).  It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target	</t> word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.  It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is made.
The role specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> takes place.

This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
A mutual commitment to an obligation made by two or more parties.
A salient entity, an activity or behavior by the parties to the agreement to which a particular stipulation pertains.
The <fen>Requirements</fen> that a particular stipulation of the <fen>Agreement</fen> imposes on one or both of the parties.
An event or state of affairs that is desirable to some or all of the parties to the <fen>Agreement</fen> and which is conditional on the <fen>Requirements</fen> being met.
A party who demands that certain <fen>Requirements</fen> be met before they will enter into an <fen>Agreement</fen> or allow a <fen>Desired_state_of_affairs</fen> to be realized.
The <fen>Speaker</fen>, as in other communication frames, is generally an External Argument.
In this frame the <fen>Addressee</fen> can either occur as an NP Object (usually with a following complement clause) or as a PP Complement of verbs or nouns.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the content of the request that can be expressed as a quote, in a finite or non-finite clausal Complement, an NP Object or PP Complement.

The <fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used to transmit the <fen>Message</fen>. The <fen>Medium</fen> is frequently expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>on</ment> or <ment>in</ment>.
The interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the request.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Chapter 6</fex> admonishes readers to quit smoking.
<fex>Evelyn</fex> spoke feelingly about what happened.
Evelyn said <fex>that she was not ready to leave</fex>.
Evelyn spoke candidly <fex>about her past</fex>.
Kim preached to me <fex>over the phone</fex>.
In some remarks <fex>at the National Press Club</fex>, Mr. Keating said he would make a better prime minister tha nMr. Hawke.
Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
The right to remove tenants ' fixtures may be given by the terms <fex>of the lease</fex>.
Many believed that the <fex>military</fex> terms of the armistice made the resumption of hostilities virtually impossible for Germany.
Each time you use the site, a condition of use is <fex>that you comply with the above terms</fex>.
What are your conditions <fex>of Sale</fex>?
<fex>Our</fex> political and military terms of peace will be designed to prevent a repetition of Germany's misdeeds
<fex>The judge</fex> ordered the plaintiff to return the money.
The child implored <fex>her parents</fex> to let her stay up late.
<fex>'I'd like an extension,'</fex> begged Pat.
The parents of the missing child made an appeal <fex>on television</fex>.
I urged him to concede <fex>yesterday</fex>.
